newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: Fall in NZ trade balance trend continues in April.
newsitem.headline: Fall in NZ trade balance trend continues in April.

text.p: New Zealand's merchandise trade balance trend continued to decline in April, Statistics New Zealand (SNZ) said on Monday.

"The imports trend has risen from a low point in October 1996 by an average of 1.2 percent per month. The exports trend has recorded an average monthly decline of 0.9 percent from a high point in September 1996," SNZ said.

For the year ended April, the trade deficit was valued at NZ$541.1 million, compared with a $997.7 million deficit in the year ended April 1996.

Unadjusted exports for the year ended April were valued at $20.93 billion, up 1.9 percent on the previous April year. The major export commodities were milk powder, butter and cheese valued at $3.51 billion, meat valued at $2.72 billion and wood valued at $1.54 billion.

Unadjusted imports for the year ended April were valued at $21.47 billion, down 0.3 percent from the previous year. The major import commodities were mechanical machinery (valued at $3.37 billion), vehicles ($2.86 billion) and electrical machinery ($2.2 billion).
SNZ said that excluding large irregular items, such as aircraft and ships, the deficit for the April 1997 year would have been reduced to $436 million.
